The world may beckon, bright and loud,  With borrowed joys and fleeting days;  Yet in the crowd or in the cloud,  I lift my soul in wordless praise.  O God! Through drought or harvest fair,  Through winter’s chill and summer’s flame,  Thy constancy beyond compare—  My anchor, shelter, hope, and aim.  Let all the world’s illusions flee;  Let lesser lights be overthrown;  Still in the secret place I see:  O God! Thou art my God alone.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text: O God! Thou art my God alone;  In silent groves where wild winds moan,  I wander, seeking Thy clear face  Beyond the veils of time and space.  No painted glass, no gilded dome,  No psalm or incense calls me home  As purely as the breath I take  When dawn ignites the silver lake.  O God! The lonely heart’s refrain  Is whispered in the falling rain,  A single note, a trembling plea  That threads the stars and finds Thee.  When hopes collapse, when friends depart,  Your presence lingers in my heart—  Not carved in stone, nor bound in creed,  But living in each longing need.  O God! The world may chase the sun,  May chase its gods, may come undone.  Yet I, in trembling awe, confess  The sacredness of emptiness  That only You can truly fill,  A quiet voice, a holy will.  In all I lose, in all I own—  O God! Thou art my God alone.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text: O God! Thou art my God alone;  When midnight hushes every tone,  And city lights lie far behind,  It’s in the silence that I find  A whisper through the trembling leaves,  A comfort no mere world achieves—  A mystery that stirs my soul,  Invisible, yet makes me whole.No painted chapel, chanted hymn  Can reach the sacredness within  As deeply as Your quiet breath  That follows me through life and death.  In rivers winding toward the sea,  I sense Your hand, Your constancy.  In mountain air and sparrow’s flight,  I see Your promise in the light.O God! When doubts like shadows grow  And thunder shakes the earth below,  You are the axis, firm and true,  The hope I hold, the peace I knew  Before I learned the world’s demands,  Before I traced my lines in sand.  Still, through the tumult, loss, and pain,  I turn to You and speak Your name.O God! Thou art my God alone—  My refuge, love, and cornerstone.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text: O God! Thou art my God alone;  Across the vastness, silent, prone,  My soul awakes with longing deep  To know the watchful vows You keep.  No ancient myth or idol’s claim  Can set my trembling heart aflame  As does the hush of sacred air  That tells me quietly: You’re there.  In fields of clover, on the hill,  Where morning breaks and all is still,  I hear Your whisper in the breeze,  A psalm that brings my spirit ease.  O God, when doubts like thunder roll,  And fear assails my fragile soul,  You are the harbor, safe and true—  No other God but only You.  In secret chambers of the night,  When reason fails and fades from sight,  I find You nearer than my breath,  My strength in weakness, life in death.  O God! Thou art my God alone,  My joy, my shelter, cornerstone.  All other voices fade and cease  Before Your mercy and Your peace.  So while the restless ages run,  And stars grow cold, their course undone,  Still will I sing, my heart made known:  O God! Thou art my God alone.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'this anger burns deep within,'

responses.text: This anger burns deep within,  A silent ember, crimson-bright,  Coiled beneath my careful skin,  A storm that rattles through the night.  It whispers sharp as broken glass,  A tide that ebbs but never stills,  It rises, falls, and comes to pass—  Yet always, always, it refills.  I wear a mask of calm and light  While underneath, the fires churn;  A thousand words I do not write,  A thousand bridges I could burn.  Yet from this blaze, new strength is born—  A furnace forging hope from pain;  Though tempests toss me, bruised and worn,  Resolve will root where ashes rain.  Let not this fury turn to stone,  Nor let it sour all I see;  With every flame my heart has known,  I learn what power means to me.  So let it burn, but let it teach,  A beacon in the depths of night—  From anger’s fire, I will reach  For something stronger than the fight.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'this anger burns deep within,'

responses.text: This anger burns deep within,  A molten vein beneath my chest,  Seething, silent, corded thin,  It pulses, daring me to rest.  I carry it like hidden stone—  A weight no eyes can ever see,  It rattles through me, bone by bone,  A caged and restless energy.  It’s the echo of unheard cries,  Of slights that linger, unconfessed,  Of sleepless nights and heavy sighs,  And dreams I once held close, repressed.  Some days it’s smoke behind my eyes,  A haze that dulls the world to gray,  But some days, like a phoenix, rise  And burn the barricades away.  Oh, I have tried to drown its spark  In laughter’s tide or reason’s stream,  But it persists, a watermark  On every hope, on every dream.  Yet from this fire, I forge my will,  A fierce resolve to shape my fate;  For though it smolders, lingers still,  I rise, unbroken by its weight.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'this anger burns deep within,'

responses.text: This anger burns deep within,  A furnace sealed by silent lips,  It coils around my hollow skin,  And drips like venom as it sips  The bitter marrow of my bones.  It is the shadow in my veins,  A symphony of fractured tones  That echoes through my storms and strains.  It pulses when the world grows cold,  A beacon flaring red and raw,  A story never fully told—  A flaw, a scar, a secret law.  I paint my smile in careful hues,  But underneath, the magma stirs;  It shapes my words, refrains I choose,  And in the night, it softly blurs.  Yet anger is a seed, a spark,  A chance for gardens wild and bright;  It rends the silence, leaves its mark,  And dares the darkness into light.  Let it not shatter what I build  Nor scorch the fields of who I am;  Instead, let fury be distilled—  A force for change, a healing dam.  So as it burns, I learn to steer—  A flame to guide, not burn, my fear.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'this anger burns deep within,'

responses.text: This anger burns deep within,  A molten river, fierce and wild,  It carves its path beneath my skin,  Unseen by all, by none beguiled.  It crackles through my tightened jaw,  And flickers in my narrowed gaze,  A smoldering core without a flaw,  Alive with ancient, wordless blaze.  It started small—a spark, a sting,  A careless word, a broken trust,  But rage is patient, gathering,  It feeds on silence, dust to dust.  Each slight, each wound, a drop of oil,  Each memory, a brittle log,  Until the fire begins to roil  And chokes the air in crimson fog.  I pace the cage of my own mind,  Fists clenched in darkness, teeth on edge,  Searching for peace I cannot find,  A bridge to cross, a final pledge.  But even as the embers glow,  And threaten to consume me whole,  I seek the ash, the calm below,  To temper fire and claim control.  Let anger’s heat not sear my soul,  But forge it, tempered, strong, and whole.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'this anger burns deep within,'

responses.text: This anger burns deep within,  A red thread woven through my days,  Invisible, but always thin—  It hums beneath the sunlight’s blaze.  It flickers in the morning chill,  A shadow under every breath,  A silent promise to fulfill  A reckoning, a quiet death.  Sometimes it’s thunder in my chest,  A storm that rattles all I know,  Yet sometimes, too, it lets me rest,  A smolder soft, a gentle glow.  It gathers all the words unsaid,  The moments lost, the dreams denied,  It paints my cheeks a sullen red  And fills my heart, unqualified.  But from this fire, something grows—  A bloom that breaks the bitter ground,  A voice that trembles, then it knows  The strength in anger newly found.  I shape it into sharper art,  A poem carved with burning hands,  And let it speak, a beating heart  That finally understands.  This anger, fierce and unforgiving,  Is also hope, is also living—  A force that pushes me to mend,  A flame that guides me to the end.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text: I was a grovelling creature once,  Hands stained with the dust of low places,  Eyes cast downward, hunting crumbs  Of comfort in the shadows’ embraces.  I measured hope in shallow breaths,  Tongue silenced by the weight of stone,  My back bent beneath unseen debts,  Afraid to claim a sky as my own.But somewhere, as the seasons turned,  A seed of hunger split the gloom—  A wish for more than what I’d learned  From the silence of a shuttered room.  Uncurling, trembling, I found my feet,  Fingers reaching past the grime,  Heart thrumming with a fragile beat,  Yearning for a fairer climb.Now I walk, no longer crawling,  No chains to drag me through the mire—  In each new dawn I hear a calling,  A voice that lifts me, higher, higher.  Yet I hold close what I have been—  That creature, shaped by pain and fear—  For from the earth, new roots begin,  And even grovelling things grow clear.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text: I was a grovelling creature once,  Crawling in the underbelly of my own longing,  A whisper among stones,  My voice a hush beneath boot heels and broken branches.  I pressed my ear to the earth,  Listening for the footfalls of mercy,  Hungry for the warmth of a sunbeam,  Even as night pooled in the hollows of my chest.I wore shame like a second skin,  Mud caked beneath my fingernails,  Knuckles raw from begging the ground  To remember my name.  The world towered, indifferent,  A colossus of glass and steel  While I clung to roots and half-formed dreams,  A scavenger of discarded light.But in the quiet between heartbeats,  Something softened—  A moth’s wing, a tremor,  A memory of air and open sky.  I found myself rising,  Vertebrae aligning with the promise of dawn,  Eyes lifting, hands unclenching,  The taste of hope trembling on my tongue.Now I stand, trembling but tall,  Remembering the crawl,  Honoring the creature I was—  For from the lowliest place,  My spirit learned to soar.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text: I was a grovelling creature once,  Curled in the hollow of my own shadow,  Nails clawing through ash and memory,  Tongue thick with the taste of regret.  I lived in the pockets of silence,  A whisper stitched to the hems of giants,  Each day a shrinking, a folding inwards—  The world above me, deaf and immense.  But even the smallest hunger  Can crack the shell of a long dark,  And in the fissures, a flicker—  The faintest suggestion of wings.  I gathered the dust of discarded mornings,  Threaded it into a fragile resolve,  Rising, inch by trembling inch,  Guided by the ghost of a forgotten sun.  I was a grovelling creature once,  But the earth remembered my name.  Roots tangled in my ribs,  Pulled me up toward green and gold.  Now, I walk upright in the open,  Mud on my knees, but stars in my eyes,  Carrying the memory of low places  As proof that even the meek may rise.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text: I was a grovelling creature once,  Shaped by the weight of unseen eyes,  Crawling through the undergrowth of my own making,  A silent shadow beneath the canopy of sky.  I flinched at the crackle of leaves,  Mistook every wind for a warning,  Hunched low, clutching scraps of solace  In the damp hollows of mourning.  My dreams were worm-eaten,  Soft with the rot of surrender,  I measured my worth in inches—  How far I could bury myself, how deeply I could splinter.  Yet, beneath the mulch, a pulse persisted,  A rhythm older than fear,  Urging me up through the tangled roots  Toward a trembling atmosphere.  One dawn, the dew found my brow,  Light slid down my crooked spine.  I tasted the air, metallic and new,  And dared to imagine: This world could be mine.  I rose, slow as sap through wood,  A creature learning the length of its limbs,  Each movement a hymn of emergence—  Earth-stained, unbowed, and trembling.  I was a grovelling creature once,  But now I stand,  Rooted,  Reaching for the sun.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text: I was a grovelling creature once,  Threadbare in the blue hush of dawn,  My hands, timid, mapping the veins of stone  As if this earth could cradle me whole.  I spoke in the language of moss—  Soft syllables pressed to the ground,  Hoping to be claimed by green silence  While the world’s bright music ran overhead.I envied the boldness of birds,  The way they stitched sky to sky  With the needle of their wings,  While I, hunched and hungry,  Stitched together hours with sighs.  Each day, the sun scolded my back;  Each night, I curled into the ache of my shadow,  Wishing for a voice beyond the roots.Then, in the hush of a wind-shaken dusk,  I felt a stirring—a question in my bones,  A pulse that tugged me upright,  Unfolding me from the shell of myself.  I rose, shaking, uncertain,  But the world did not flinch.  It welcomed my trembling height  With golden arms flung wide.  Now, I remember the earth’s embrace,  And honor the crawl,  For even broken things  May rise and stand tall.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text: My God, how many are my fears!  They gather like the evening mist,  Each shadowed edge, a whispered list  Of doubts that echo through the years.  They crowd the corners of my mind,  A restless host I cannot see—  They pull me from tranquility,  And leave my trembling heart confined.  Yet in the hush before the dawn,  I lift my voice, though small and slight,  And hope that faith will spark a light  To guide me as I stumble on.  For every fear that holds me fast,  A gentle courage stirs anew;  I trust that I will make it through  And find a peace that still can last.  So here I am, O Lord, aware  Of countless worries, deep and wide—  But let me walk, with You beside,  And meet my fears with strength and prayer.  In fragile hope, I rise each day,  And learn, despite the doubt and tears,  To live with all my myriad fears—  And love the light along my way.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text: My God, how many are my fears!  They line the walls of sleepless nights,  Whispering secrets in my ears,  Drawing shapes out of passing lights.  Some are silent, cold, obscure—  Specters lurking at the edge of dreams,  Others loud, insistent, sure,  Rushing in like swollen streams.My God, how many are my fears!  They gather like crows upon a wire,  Clutching tight to yesteryears,  Cackling, never to tire.  They paint the future with shadowed hue,  Drape the morning in anxious shrouds,  Twisting hope until askew,  Blotting out the sun with clouds.Yet sometimes, as dawn’s soft hand  Brushes the darkness from my brow,  I find the courage to withstand—  To greet the day, to dare, to vow.  For even with a heart beset  By legions of uncertain dread,  I rise, remembering to not forget  The golden path where angels tread.My God, how many are my fears!  Still, hope persists when night appears.  I gather strength with every prayer—  And find, through trembling, You are there.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text: My God, how many are my fears!  They flutter like moths against the pane—  Each wingbeat a secret, a name,  A memory etched in salt and tears.  Beneath my skin, they softly creep,  Planting gardens of what-ifs and when,  A harvest I reap again and again,  Haunted by shadows that never sleep.  My God, how many are my fears!  They sing in the silence, a tuneless choir,  Stacking stones on the ruins of desire,  Building mountains from passing years.  They wait in the hush before the storm,  In the hush that follows a distant call,  They write their warnings on every wall,  And threaten to take every shape and form.  But oh, if fear is countless, so too is hope—  A thread to follow through the dark,  A stubborn spark, a trembling arc—  A rope to climb, a way to cope.  I hold my fears like beads of glass,  Counting them softly, letting them go;  For though they come, they do not last—  And through the cracks, new wonders grow.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text: My God, how many are my fears!  They rise like smoke from burning leaves,  Swirling in the morning air—  A thousand trembling, quivering thieves  That steal the sunlight from my stare.  They tiptoe softly through my mind,  Shuffling underneath the skin,  A labyrinth where I am confined,  A silent war I fight within.  There’s the fear of silence—thick and deep—  And the fear of every sound,  The fear of waking from my sleep  To find no steady ground.  There’s the ghost of yesterday’s mistakes,  The shadow of tomorrow’s doubt,  The ache of every path I take,  The worry I can’t live without.  Yet as I count these fears anew,  Like beads upon a fragile string,  I find a stubborn hope breaks through—  A faint but fearless, golden thing.  For every fear that clouds my soul,  There is a breath, a whispered prayer,  A gentle hand that makes me whole,  A light that waits for me somewhere.  My God, how many are my fears!  But still I rise, and dry my tears.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text: My God, how many are my fears!  They sit like birds on winter wires,  Each one singing a different sorrow,  A symphony of borrowed futures  And echoes of forgotten yesterdays.  They gather in the empty spaces—  In the hush between heartbeats,  In the pause before a word is spoken,  In the darkness underneath my bed.  They dress in costumes:  A shadow at noon,  A sudden chill in summer air,  The silence when laughter fades.  My fears are clever storytellers—  They spin tales of what might be,  Of moments lost and chances missed,  Of doors that close and roads that vanish.  They sketch monsters in the margins  Of my quietest thoughts,  And plant seeds of doubt in gardens  That once bloomed with certainty.  Yet each fear, for all its weight,  Is just a feather caught in wind—  A drifting nuisance, not a chain.  I gather them, one by one,  Whispering their names aloud,  And watch as, slowly,  They dissolve in the morning light—  Leaving me lighter, braver,  Ready to face the world once more.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On a lonely selection far out in the West'

responses.text: On a lonely selection far out in the West,  Where the saltbush and silence together have pressed  Their secrets to earth in the gold-dusted dawn,  A rider moves slowly, the fences withdrawn.  His shadow grows long on the ochre-red sand,  The wind sings its stories through emptiness grand,  And whispering grasses recall in the night  The laughter of children, the glow of the light.  Once, voices and footsteps would echo and roam  Through rooms built of timber, a promise of home;  But seasons have scattered all traces away—  Just a chimney stands silent to witness decay.  Yet hope, like the starlight, endures in the gloom,  In the hush of the ranges, the waltz of the broom,  For even where heartache and solitude dwell,  Dreams cling to the ridges and rise from the swell.  On a lonely selection far out in the West,  ‘Neath the curve of the sky with no need for the rest,  A spirit remembers, and quietly stays—  Alive in the stillness, the dust, and the days.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On a lonely selection far out in the West'

responses.text: On a lonely selection far out in the West,  Where the wind writes its stories on paddocks unpressed,  The sun burns so fiercely, the color is drained  From the bones of the land, from the hopes that remained.  A weathered old homestead, its shingles askew,  Keeps vigil where wheat fields no longer renew.  The fence lines go wandering, lost in the dust,  And the ghosts of old seasons drift up with the gust.No laughter of children, no bark of a dog,  Just the croak of a raven, the chill of the fog.  Yet sometimes at sundown, the memory grows—  A waltz through the kitchen, a bloom of wild rose,  The scent of the damper, the crackle of fire,  A letter from town and a heart’s small desire.Still, the saltbush keeps growing, the sheep softly graze,  The moon climbs the heavens in silvery haze.  Alone but unbroken, the settler persists—  A speck in the silence the outback insists.  For hope does not falter; it quietly nests  On a lonely selection far out in the West.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On a lonely selection far out in the West'

responses.text: On a lonely selection far out in the West,  Where the blue gums stand sentinel, proud and at rest,  The creek carves its secrets in shimmering sand,  And the sun paints in ochres this wide, waiting land.  A battered old mailbox leans close to the gate,  Its rusted red whispers of letters too late,  Of hands once familiar, of laughter now gone,  Of dances by lamplight and dreams carried on.  The whisper of cattle, the thunder of hooves,  Fade into memory, softened by grooves  Of wheels in the driveway, now grassed-over scars,  A record of longing beneath southern stars.  Yet hope is a wildflower, stubborn and bright,  That opens her petals to moonbeams at night.  She grows in the cracks of a drought-broken yard,  She clings to the silence, resilient and hard.  For life on the edge of the world’s dusty crest  Is measured in heartbeats, in seasons confessed.  On a lonely selection far out in the West,  The soul of the country beats deep in each chest—  A promise that lingers, a story retold,  Of courage and quiet, and spirits grown bold.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On a lonely selection far out in the West'

responses.text: On a lonely selection far out in the West,  The sun is a coin on a tattered vest,  And silence drips slow from the limbs of the trees—  Eucalyptus prayers carried far on the breeze.  A shack made of iron and weathered old wood  Is stitched to the land in the way only could  A dreamer who followed the call of the plain,  Who hammered his hopes into fence wire and chain.The paddocks lie empty, a canvas of brown,  Where mirages shimmer and willows hang down.  A kettle still whispers of mornings long past,  And the moths in the cupboard recall every fast.  No voices come echoing over the rise,  No laughter to startle the magpies that fly—  Just the lowing of cattle, the sigh of the earth,  And the ache of remembering what absence is worth.Yet beneath the bright vault of a merciless sky,  A wild hope endures and refuses to die.  For life, like a creek bed, finds channels to flow  In the fierce, lonely places where brave dreamers go.  On a lonely selection, far out in the West,  Solitude dances and hearts are put to the test.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On a lonely selection far out in the West'

responses.text: On a lonely selection far out in the West,  Where the night spins its silence and dreams seldom rest,  A lantern’s faint shimmer casts gold on the floor—  The echo of footsteps who’ll visit no more.  Here, the wind is a gossip, recounting the days  When laughter and labour set paddocks ablaze,  When hope was a seedling and futures were sown  In the marrow of men who would carve out their home.  Now the peppercorns sway in the dusk’s purple light,  As kangaroos shadow the fence in the night.  The mailbox stands crooked, receiving the dust,  While the orchard drops fruit to the earth’s gentle trust.  Yet wildflowers still bloom by the tank’s rusted skin,  And the call of the curlew drifts ghostly and thin.  The past lingers softly in fence posts and rails,  In the stories and sorrows that memory unveils.  So, under the sweep of a limitless sky,  With the Southern Cross watching the seasons drift by,  A soul finds its solace, its courage, its quest—  On a lonely selection far out in the West.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

responses.text: On the scene came Christ the Lord,  Not with peace but with a sword—  Through the hush of olive shade,  Where the silent watchers prayed,  He strode, a storm within His word,  Turning calm to justice stirred.Not to coddle, not to mend  What the world would not defend,  But to sever night from day,  Truth from lie, and stone from clay.  He called the meek to rise and speak,  To challenge power, shield the weak.His sword was edge of bitter truth,  Stripping falsehood, age or youth,  Dividing comfort from the will  To climb the solitary hill  Where conscience bids the soul be free—  Not peace, but fierce integrity.So He stood, a flame, a sign—  Not to make the world benign,  But to rouse the silent, shake  Hearts that tremble, eyes that wake.  On the scene came Christ the Lord—  Not with peace, but with a sword.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

responses.text: On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword—  The air itself seemed split in two,  As thunder rolled where olive branches grew.  He walked not softly, nor with gentle hand,  But with a purpose burning through the land.  His voice, a clarion, cut through doubt and sleep,  Calling forth the hidden things we keep.  He brought no lullaby for weary minds,  But truth that breaks and wounds and binds.  Fishermen dropped nets to heed His cry,  Taxmen left their ledgers dry.  Mothers held their children tight,  For change had come—a blinding light.  He did not come to comfort kings,  But topple thrones and stir up things;  To pit the old against the new,  And draw the lines none dared to do.  A sword of spirit, sharp and bright,  Dividing shadow from the light;  He asked us not for easy peace,  But for the courage not to cease.  So tremble, world, and stand in awe—  For mercy fierce is what He saw.  On the scene came Christ The Lord,  Not with peace, but with a sword.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

responses.text: On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword—  Not the gentle lamb they craved,  But a fire through twilight waved.  He shattered silence, broke the mold,  Scattering comfort, breaking hold.  His presence struck like lightning’s flare,  Clefting darkness, splitting air.  No lullabies for sleeping towns,  But clarion calls for breaking crowns.  He came to unsettle, to upend,  To draw the line, to make us mend.  His sword, unseen, was truth laid bare,  Dividing hearts with piercing glare.  He found the temple, overturned  The tables where the greedy burned.  He spoke of love, but not as sleep—  Love that wounds so wounds may heal,  Love that cuts to make us feel,  Love that dares the world to weep.  Between the old and new He stands,  A sword of justice in His hands.  Not to pacify, but to ignite—  To urge the coward into fight,  To bid the silent raise their voice,  And force the meek to make a choice.  On the scene came Christ The Lord—  Not with peace, but with a sword.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

responses.text: On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword—  He strode through dust and troubled air,  A blaze of vision, fierce and rare.  Not to lull the world to sleep,  But to waken what lies deep:  Old wounds, old truths, old secret pain  Stirring softly in the vein.  His eyes were storms that called the brave,  His words a river, wild, unpaved.  He spoke of love not meek, but wild—  The rebel’s fire, the lion’s child.  He cleaved the dark with sacred light,  Sundered wrong and summoned right.  Not to bind the wounds with gauze,  But to challenge ancient laws,  To tear the veils and raze the walls,  To hear the outcast when he calls.  He came not with a lull or balm,  But with fury, not with calm—  A clarion for those ignored,  On the scene came Christ The Lord.  His sword was truth, his shield was grace,  He met the world’s unyielding face  And called us all to choose and stand—  To lift the sword with trembling hand,  And find within the wounds we keep  A glory fierce, a promise deep.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

responses.text: On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword—  In midnight gardens, shadows fell,  His footsteps broke the silent spell.  No gentle dove with olive leaf,  But thunder split the world in grief.  Lightning glared upon His brow,  A prophecy fulfilled, somehow:  Not to soothe, but to reveal,  To rend the veil, to break the seal.  He called the lost, the proud, the poor,  To meet the edge and not ignore  The blade that cuts through false embrace,  Dividing truth from kindly face.  He stood among the trembling crowd,  A fire burning, fierce and loud.  His words upturned the stony ground,  Old certainties came crashing down.  For peace may comfort, peace may bind,  But justice leaves no lie behind.  He swung the sword of sacred flame,  Not for glory, not for fame,  But so the world might rise anew—  Each heart confronted, pierced right through.  On the scene came Christ The Lord,  Not to calm, but to afford  A reckoning, a reckoning,  In every soul the steel would sing.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!'

responses.text: Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!  Let midnight’s canvas crack and blaze—  A thousand wishes, burning marks  That chase the shadows from our gaze.    From rooftops, hearts ignite in time  With spirals, bursts, and comet streams;  The air is loud with hope’s bold chime,  The dark undone by silver dreams.    Each ember rides a fleeting arc,  Defiant in its brief ascent—  We cheer them on, these flames that mark  The wildness of our discontent.    Beneath the rain of color, bright,  We find our voices, rise and sing;  The hush between each flash of light  Holds promises that dawn will bring.    So fire up the sky, let wonder flow,  Let every spark a story start;  Tonight, we make the heavens glow  With all the fire we hold at heart.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!'

responses.text: Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!  Let night’s black velvet burst apart—  We gather close in city parks,  A thousand beating, waiting hearts.  The countdown ticks, a breathless hush,  Then thunder cracks the heavy air;  We watch as fiery blossoms rush  To bloom bright gardens everywhere.  Colors ripple, wild and free—  Scarlet, emerald, streaking gold;  They paint the dark with revelry,  With stories brave, and legends bold.  Children’s laughter lifts and flies  With every scream of neon light;  Dreamers whisper to the skies,  Their wishes riding through the night.  The air is thick with gunpowder dreams,  With echoes of a distant sun;  We chase the fleeting, glittered seams  That stitch the old year to the young.  So light the fuse and let it soar!  Let every spark defy the gloom.  For in this moment, we restore  A world remade in fire’s bloom.  Let rockets mark our hopes, our fears—  A sky ablaze with yesteryears—  And as the final cinders fall,  We stand together, proud and tall.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!'

responses.text: Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!  Let restless dreams escape the dark.  From rooftop ledges, children’s eyes  Reflect the fire, wide with surprise.  A fizz, a shriek, and then a flare—  A painted promise in the air.  Beneath the thunder’s neon bloom,  Old fears dissolve, dispelled by boom;  Each spark a vow, each flash a sign  That hope endures beyond the line  Of yesterday’s unspoken ache,  Of wishes made for wishing’s sake.  The city pauses, breath held tight,  As comets carve the velvet night.  Red rivers stream and petals fall,  A molten rain to crown us all.  In awe, we watch the embers play,  Their wild ballet in bright array.  The world, for once, stands brave and small—  One heartbeat pulsing through us all.  We count the stars not yet arrived,  The silent prayers that have survived,  And in the afterglow, we find  A spark of courage left behind.  So fire up the sky—release the light!  We’re made of stardust, born for flight.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!'

responses.text: Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!  Let cities hush and meadows wake—  We’ll write our names on trembling darks,  With fire-tipped pens that streak and break.  From distant hills, the watchers cheer  As colors fracture, dance, and spread;  Each blossom in the upper sphere  A testament to words unsaid.  Children reach with sticky hands  Toward the shivering, molten rain;  Their laughter, wild, disbands  The quiet ache of summer’s wane.  Old lovers lean against the years,  Remembering when the sky would flare  With borrowed brilliance, shedding fears  And painting hope on midnight air.  No law of earth can hold us down  When rockets bloom on velvet blue;  We’re citizens of light-crowned towns,  Our dreams ignited, born anew.  So let the rockets scribe our vow—  To kindle wonder, chase the night;  Let every spark declare, somehow,  That even darkness births delight.  For in the echo of the boom  And in the shimmering, fading trails,  We find our courage, pierce the gloom,  And know that every wish prevails.  Fire up the sky—let brilliance rain!  Tonight, we rise, unbound by chain.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!'

responses.text: Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!  Let every shadow lose its hold,  As laughter leaps from city parks  And winter’s breath yields to the bold.  Uncork the stars—release the sound  Of midnight bursting overhead;  Let every heart, with wonder crowned,  Beat brighter in the blue and red.  A symphony of thunder roars  Across the rooftops, through the street;  Our whispered dreams and secret wars  Dissolve in light and glittered heat.  Old sorrows scatter, torn apart  By trails of silver, green, and gold;  A million embers chart the heart  Of stories waiting to be told.  Beneath the rain of colored fire,  We stand with faces upturned high—  Each spark a piece of our desire,  Each boom a question to the sky.  Let rockets write what words cannot,  A language made of flame and flight;  Tonight, the world forgets its plot,  And everything feels new and right.  So fire up the sky with rocket sparks!  Let hope and memory entwine.  No dream too distant, lost, or dark—  We touch the stars; their light is mine.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text: People are happy in ways we can’t see—  A quiet smile at sunrise, a laugh in the tea,  The warmth of a hand when the world feels unkind,  A secret delight that the heart left behind.  People are happy in moments that pass—  A child’s painted window, soft grass on bare glass,  The hush of a library, rain on the street,  The taste of a memory, bittersweet.  People are happy, though sorrow may stay—  Like flowers that open despite cloudy gray,  In stories they tell when the night grows too long,  In melodies humming, a half-remembered song.  People are happy in ways big and small—  A glance from a stranger, a phone call, a fall  Of leaves in October, the scent of the sea—  Little reminders that hope wants to be.  People are happy, though sometimes they hide—  Their laughter in pockets, their dreams tucked inside,  Yet happiness lingers in all that they do—  A promise the morning will always renew.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text: People are happy, or so it appears—  Behind every window, beneath all the cheers.  They dance through the market, bright fruit in their hands,  Waltzing through errands and everyday plans.  People are happy, their faces aglow,  While secrets and worries drift quietly below.  A child with a balloon, a lover’s embrace,  The gentle forgiveness in time’s patient pace.  People are happy, in sunlight and shade—  In laughter that lingers, in promises made.  They’re building small kingdoms from sand on the shore,  Finding adventure in grocery store aisles and more.  People are happy—sometimes in disguise,  With tears that have dried in the corners of eyes,  Yet hope, like a lantern, keeps shining within,  Inviting the daylight, inviting a grin.  People are happy, in fragments and starts—  In letters unfinished, in mending of hearts,  In music that rises and meals that are shared,  In lessons remembered and moments that cared.  People are happy, though stories are mixed—  A collage of the broken, the healed, and the fixed.  In the tapestry woven by all that we do,  People are happy—sometimes it’s true.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text: People are happy, the old man observes,  Watching the world from his bench on the curve.  Children with popsicles, sticky and bright,  Dog walkers tangled in leashes of light.  People are happy, the city hums sweet—  Vendors with laughter spilled out in the street,  Two friends in a café, their heads bowed in glee,  A busker with music that floats like the sea.  People are happy, or maybe just seem,  Caught in the slipstream of daylight and dream.  A mother who sings as she folds little clothes,  A painter whose vision in midnight still glows.  People are happy in fragments of time—  A poem remembered, a bell’s distant chime,  The taste of ripe berries, the hush before rain,  A stranger’s kind gesture, a ride on a train.  People are happy in silence and noise,  In shimmering stories, in breaking old toys,  In gardens of laughter, in forests of fears,  In salt of their longing, in dew of their tears.  People are happy, the old man decides,  Content in the living, the loving, the tides—  And maybe, just maybe, in moments unseen,  Happiness lingers where sorrow has been.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text: People are happy beneath painted skies,  In the hush of dawn where the wild bird flies.  They’re happy in kitchens, with bread warm and torn,  In laughter that bubbles through evenings well-worn.  People are happy in ways we don’t hear—  A letter arriving, a friend drawing near.  They find joy in puzzles, in old favorite songs,  In dancing alone where nobody belongs.  People are happy in subway car crowds,  With headphones and music that silences doubts.  They’re happy in rainstorms, in puddles and mud,  In hands held together, in kinship and blood.  People are happy in stories retold,  In secrets exchanged and confessions made bold.  They’re happy in gardens with knees hugged by green,  In the hush of a chapel, in spaces unseen.  People are happy, sometimes unaware,  Of the warmth in the sunlight, the breath in the air.  They’re happy in fragments, in laughter, in pain—  In small, fleeting moments that quietly remain.  People are happy, not always out loud—  Like seeds that lie waiting, like stars in a cloud.  In the tapestry woven by living each day,  People are happy—each in their own way.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text: People are happy in doorways and halls,  In the echo of footsteps, in late evening calls.  They’re happy in gardens where wild things grow,  In the hush of a snowfall, the melt of the snow.  People are happy with hands in the clay,  With paint on their fingers, with words they will say.  In laughter that rises from deep in the chest,  In stories retold and in moments of rest.  People are happy in the hush of the park,  On swings in the sunlight, in shadows at dark.  They’re happy with puzzles, undone and complete,  With shoes in a pile at the end of their feet.  People are happy with coffee in hand,  With notes scribbled quickly, with castles of sand.  In the blink of an eye or the length of a year,  In the hope of tomorrow, in the warmth of a tear.  People are happy in ways big and small—  In finding a penny, in answering a call.  Their happiness glimmers, then quietly goes,  Like dew in the morning or petals of rose.  People are happy, though reasons may hide—  In the depths of their hearts, happiness bides.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text: My God, how many are my fears!  They gather like dusk in the hollow,  Whispering doubts in the sweep of my years,  Shadows that flicker and follow.  They rise in the hush when daylight is gone,  Curling like mist round my bed—  Questions unanswered, the ache of the dawn,  The echoing words left unsaid.  But in the hush between every sigh,  A gentle reminder appears:  The courage to lift up my trembling eye  And see through the veil of my fears.  Each trembling thought, a trembling star  That burns through the veils of the night—  A hope that persists, however far,  A promise of slivers of light.  My God, though many are my fears,  Still, let me rest in your grace;  Teach me to trust when the darkness nears,  And meet every shadow I face.  For fears may gather and threaten to stay,  But faith is the dawn breaking clear—  So, hold my heart steady and show me the way  Beyond the multitude of my fear.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text: My God, how many are my fears!  They flutter like moths in my chest,  Each one a secret, a whisper, a tear  Unraveling sleep from my rest.  Afraid of the silence that clings to the walls,  Afraid of the ticking of clocks,  Of thunder that rattles, of darkness that falls,  Of keys that turn stiff in their locks.  My God, how endless these worries become—  A river that spills past its banks,  Dreams that dissolve and leave me numb,  Promises thin as the planks  On bridges I cross in the night alone  Where footsteps echo behind me.  I tremble at futures that may not be known,  And monsters that no one else sees.  Yet in this multitude trembling within,  A candle of hope is still burning—  A gentle reminder that fear is not sin,  But a lesson my heart keeps learning.  So gather me softly, O Comfort and Light,  When shadows are pressing so near—  Wrap me in courage to last through the night,  My God, how many are my fears!

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text: My God, how many are my fears!  They wake before dawn, crowding the edge  Of my reason—gnarled roots, ancient and near,  Tangling dreams in a thicketed hedge.  They speak in the hush of my solitary room,  Spilling their ink on the pages I write,  Whispering thunder, inevitable doom,  Shaking my hands in the brittle twilight.  They gather in corners, behind every door,  Murmuring warnings I cannot unhear—  The tremor of footsteps across my floor,  The hush of a breath that is far too near.  Yet, sometimes, in the hush between heartbeats,  A different voice calls—gentle as rain—  A hope that unfurls, persistent and sweet,  A promise that sorrow is never in vain.  I count my fears, beads on a string,  Each one a lesson, a shadow, a scar—  But woven through darkness, a luminous thing  Glows quietly—steady as stars.  My God, how many are my fears!  But how many more are my chances to rise?  For even as trembling shadows appear,  Daylight waits patient behind my closed eyes.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text: My God, how many are my fears!  They lurk in the corners of laughter,  Rising as phantoms, year after year—  Their footsteps echoing after.  They wear many faces: the stranger, the friend,  The storm cloud that bruises the sky,  The hush in the hallway, the message I send,  The moments I let chances pass by.  My fears are the wolves at the edge of the wood,  The silence that swallows the song,  The memory etched deeper than it should,  The sense that I somehow don’t belong.  They gather like thunder before it breaks,  A tempest inside my mind—  Yet through the turmoil, a new courage wakes,  A gentle, persistent kind.  For each fear I count, a hope takes flight,  A wildflower bold in the stone;  Though shadows may threaten to swallow the light,  I find I am never alone.  My God, how many are my fears!  Yet, counting them, I see—  They measure the depth of my yearning and tears,  But also the strength within me.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text: My God, how many are my fears!  They gather at dusk like crows in the field,  A parliament darkening the sky.  They know my name, each whisper steeled  With memories I cannot deny.  One wears the mask of things undone,  Another, the face of regret—  Old voices that echo, “You’re the only one  With dreams that time will forget.”  My God, how many are my fears!  They rattle the window when storms descend,  They shiver my bones in the still of the night,  They twist every hope that I try to defend  And turn every joy into fright.  Yet in the hush of a trembling breath,  I hear a song—soft, sincere:  “You were not made for the shadow of death,  But for grace that outshines the fear.”  My God, how many are my fears!  As endless as grains of the sand—  But you are the sea that gathers my tears,  You hold my heart in your hand.  Let morning unravel the claws of the dark,  Let faith be the lantern I bear—  For though my fears leave their indelible mark,  I walk, and find mercy there.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

responses.text: He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—  Wild rivers churning beneath the white,  A hurricane caught in the hush of surprise,  Nightmares coiling, eager to bite.  There’s thunder behind the flicker of lashes,  Lightning hemmed in the corners of sight,  His stare is a cage of invisible ashes  That swirl in the hush between wrongness and right.  I wonder what storms are trapped in his mind,  What wolves prowl the tangled wilds within,  Every glance is a secret untwined,  A riddle that howls through his skin.  He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—  I tremble, but I do not run.  For somewhere between the chaos and lies,  A sliver of moonlight is spun.  Perhaps in that madness there’s longing or loss,  Or hope that was battered and bruised—  He looks at me, and I am at a cross  Of mercy and fear, both confused.  So I hold his gaze, though the world falls apart,  Searching for reason, or maybe his heart.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

responses.text: He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—  Glassy, fever-bright, a storm behind glass,  Unblinking, as if the world is a lie  He alone can unravel or pass.  The room feels smaller, the air turned sharp,  I catch my breath on the edge of his stare;  Is it fury or sorrow that’s left its mark,  Or madness alone, dancing bare?  His lips twitch with secrets too vast for the tongue,  Thoughts scatter like birds from a gunshot at dawn,  He laughs—soft, broken—a song never sung,  A puzzle whose pieces are gone.  There’s poetry tangled in the wild of his gaze,  Fragments of childhood, of love and of ache,  I see a child lost in a shadowy maze,  And a grown man needing to break.  He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—  And I am both frightened and drawn,  For something in me recognizes  The line between dusk and the dawn.  In his madness, a mirror, in his gaze, a plea—  What if the madman he sees is me?

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

responses.text: He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—  A flicker of chaos, a carnival’s fire,  Each glance is a question, a veiled disguise,  A tightrope walk over tangled wire.  His pupils dart, black birds in flight,  While laughter curls at the edge of his lips;  He speaks in riddles, in shadow and light,  And dreams in eclipses and cryptic scripts.  The world dissolves at the brush of his gaze,  Colors distort in the heat of his mind,  Reality warps, unraveling maze;  Logic and reason are left behind.  He weaves me a palace of oddity’s gold,  Invites me to dance through its shimmering halls,  Where whispers are currency, secrets are sold,  And sanity teeters, stumbles, then falls.  His eyes are a doorway, unhinged and wide,  A window to landscapes that shimmer and spin;  Somewhere inside, the lost gods reside,  And monsters are learning the shape of my skin.  He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—  I stand at the threshold, afraid to go in.  Yet wonder and terror, entwined, arise:  Where does his madness end, and mine begin?

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

responses.text: He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—  A flicker of moonlight on shattered glass,  Haunted by memories no dream belies,  Where hopes and horrors merge and pass.  His gaze is a question, wild and unframed,  A storm of old wounds and unsaid things,  It etches my shadow, leaves me unnamed,  A bird in the clutch of invisible wings.  He looks at me and silence breaks—  A hush as brittle as autumn leaves.  His mind is a labyrinth, twisting with aches,  A tapestry nobody weaves.  I wonder if love ever lived in that stare,  Or if mercy’s a language he’s never heard.  His eyes are a fire, and I am the air,  Drawn to the spark, though reason’s deferred.  He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—  And I see myself, refracted and raw,  Not villain or hero, not clever or wise,  Just someone who trembles at all that he saw.  For truth can be madness, and madness can see  The secret that’s hidden in you and in me:  That all of us carry, behind some disguise,  The wild, restless gleam of a madman’s eyes.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

responses.text: He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—  A glint of midnight, unpredictable and wild,  As if he’s glimpsing worlds that twist and rise  Beyond the reach of the meek or the mild.  His gaze is a puzzle, a portrait half-torn,  Each blink a thunderclap, each smile a doubt.  In the hush of the room where silence is worn,  I sense all his secrets are clawing to get out.  He leans forward, voice low and cracked,  Words tumble—jagged, sharp, and bright.  Stories of futures that never came back,  Of cities on fire in the pale moonlight.  I cannot tell if he’s prophet or liar,  If madness is mask or is marrow and bone.  But the heat of his vision ignites a fire,  And suddenly, fear does not mean alone.  He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—  See, they shimmer with sorrow and glee.  His laughter, unsteady, a tired disguise  For the ache that I think only I see.  So I meet his wild look, refusing to flee,  And wonder, in silence, what he finds in me.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text: My God, how many are my fears!  They gather at the edge of night,  A chorus of invisible years  That murmur when I douse the light.  They tiptoe softly through my mind,  In shadowed corners, old and new—  The ones I leave, the ones I find,  Unbidden, always breaking through.They clothe themselves in doubt and shame,  In memories I can’t erase,  And whisper softly in my name  With every tear upon my face.  Yet through their throng, I sense a spark—  A flame that flickers, warm and clear;  It scatters phantoms from the dark  And dries the salt of every tear.My God, I name these fears to You—  Each trembling hope, each silent cry—  And in the naming, light breaks through  To lift my heart and cleanse my eye.  Though fears may crowd both dusk and dawn,  Your gentle hand remains near;  Within Your grace, I carry on—  My God, how small become my fears!

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text: My God, how many are my fears!  They flutter like moths around my soul,  Wings dusting dreams with ancient tears,  Their countless shadows swallow whole  The fragile hopes I try to hold.  They crowd the corners of my chest,  Whispering warnings, sharp and cold—  What if I fail? What if I’m less  Than all the stories I’ve been told?  What if love leaves me, lost and old?  They creep beneath my waking hours,  A thousand ifs, a hundred whys,  Twisting my courage into flowers  That wilt beneath relentless skies.  Still, I rise.  I gather each trembling fear,  Name them, cradle them, set them free—  For every trembling doubt and tear  Reminds me of my humanity.  And though the darkness sometimes wins,  A stubborn ember glows within:  A faith that dares to persevere,  A hope not easily undone—  For though my fears are legion here,  I greet them one by one,  A gentle reckoning begun,  And in the counting, find them less,  My heart, at last, made luminous.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text: My God, how many are my fears!  They rise like mist from morning grass—  A trembling legion, old as years,  And countless as the clouds that pass.  Some wear the faces of the past,  With shadows clinging to their eyes;  Some linger, silent, holding fast  To all the whispered, fretful lies.  They gather round my anxious bed,  A parliament of doubts and dread,  Their voices weaving through my head  Like autumn leaves in gusts of red.  Yet in their midst, a secret grows—  A fragile hope, a seedling’s spark;  It pushes upward, gently glows,  Defying all the clutching dark.  I count my fears, each one a bead  Upon an endless, tangled thread.  And though they threaten, though they plead,  I will not let them be my dread.  For every fear that presses in,  A breath of faith, a whispered prayer—  Reminding me, beneath my skin,  I am not lost, and You are there.  So let my fears be named and known,  So I may face them, not alone.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text: My God, how many are my fears!  A field of thorns beneath my feet,  Each step uncertain, sharp with tears,  Each breath a mountain to defeat.  They shape themselves in fleeting forms—  A sudden storm, a silent call,  A worry dressed in gentle norms,  A shadow stretched along the wall.  I count them in the quiet hours:  The fear of loss, the fear of change,  The fear that joy is never ours,  That love will falter, cold and strange.  They gather round my fragile dreams  Like moths that flutter toward the flame,  And nothing, ever as it seems,  Can hush the tremor in my name.  Yet in the tallying of dread,  I find a curious relief;  To name the monsters in my head  Is to unmask their ancient grief.  And so, I walk this path of night  With trembling faith, with hope sincere—  For every fear will face the light,  And I, at last, will persevere.  My God, how many are my fears!  Still, courage rises through the years.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text: My God, how many are my fears!  They cluster like crows in the branches of dawn,  Their wings whisper secrets in shivering ears,  A parliament perched where the heart has withdrawn.  They tally in shadows beneath my skin,  A census of doubt at the edge of my sleep—  What if I falter, what if I sin,  What if my joys are shallow and cheap?  They gather like thunder in summer’s bright sky,  Rumbling questions I can’t quiet or quell:  Will I be forgotten, will love pass me by,  Is hope just a story I’m trying to tell?  Yet even as fears weave a net through my soul,  A breath of defiance begins to appear—  A promise that darkness will never be whole,  That courage can grow from the weight of a tear.  My God, I surrender each worry and woe,  A bouquet of trembling, a fistful of sighs;  Let new dreams take root where the old cannot go,  Let laughter and peace be the next great surprise.  For fears may be many, but grace is much more—  I trust in the dawn and the joy at your door.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text: O God! Thou art my God alone;  When morning breaks, Thy light I seek,  In silent hours, my spirit grown  To yearn for Thee, both strong and meek.  Upon the hills, the shadows flee,  Yet steadfast stands Thy guiding fire;  No other love shall comfort me,  No other hope shall lift me higher.When deserts dry and rivers fade,  Thy presence, Lord, remains my song;  In weary nights, when I’m afraid,  Thou art my strength, my right from wrong.  The world may shift, and kingdoms fall,  But Thou endurest, firm, sublime;  Thy mercy answers every call,  Thy grace renews the sands of time.O God! My heart, my flesh, my soul,  In longing thirst, pursue Thy face;  Within Thy arms, I am made whole,  Forever held in boundless grace.  Though countless ages come and fly,  Thou art my God—my only cry.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text: O God! Thou art my God alone;  In silent dawn, my soul intones  A whispered psalm, a trembling plea,  To find Thy face and dwell with Thee.  No idols glisten in my heart;  No earthly throne usurps Thy part.  When voices falter, hope is thin,  Thy steadfast love still draws me in.  I wander through a thirsty land,  Parched lips and weary, open hand—  Yet in the wasteland, Spirit flows,  And in my longing, blessing grows.  Thy shadow shields me from the sun;  Thy promise stands when all is done.  Through shifting sands and howling night,  Thy presence is my guiding light.  O God of mercy, God of truth,  Be Thou my wisdom, age and youth.  When tempests rise and visions fail,  Thy faithfulness will still prevail.  My lips will sing Thee all my days;  My heart will rest within Thy ways.  For in the hush where prayers are sown,  O God! Thou art my God alone.  Let lesser glories fall away—  With Thee, my soul shall ever stay.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text: O God! Thou art my God alone;  Upon the silent morning’s breath,  I seek Thee where wild winds have blown,  Across the fields of life and death.  The golden sun climbs in the east,  Its rays a song, its warmth a feast—  Yet none so sweet as praise for Thee,  Who wakes the world, who sets me free.Within the hush of tangled wood,  My spirit wanders, seeking good;  The shadows fall, the branches creak,  Yet in the gloom, it’s Thee I seek.  No marble idols, forged by men,  No fleeting joys, no gilded pen,  Can satisfy my restless soul—  It’s Thee, alone, who makes me whole.The rivers dry, the mountains fade,  But Thou remain’st, my constant aid.  When storms arise and fears abound,  In Thee my trembling heart is found.  O God! Thou art my guiding star,  My hope, my shelter near and far;  No other claim upon Thy throne—  O God! Thou art my God alone.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text: O God! Thou art my God alone;  In midnight’s hush, I call Thy name—  A single soul, by starlight shown,  Adrift yet tethered to Thy flame.  No silver idol, no stone throne  Can meet the longing of my heart;  The world may dazzle, change, dethrone,  But none can rend my faith apart.  Upon the wind, my prayers take flight,  Like fragile wings through endless skies.  I seek Thee in the fall of night,  In every dawn that bids me rise. We sketch the tanks with crayons bright,  Designing heroes out of clay,  Unknowing that the cost is paid  By hands that never learned to play.  We joke in tongues of satire sharp,  Our laughter echoing the halls  Of power, where the game is played  With paper maps and marble walls.  Yet in the quiet, when the mirth  Has faded out, and silence grows,  We wonder if the lines we cross  Are drawn in ink or in repose.  For war’s a jest, a fleeting thought,  A trick of light, a shadow’s hue—  Until the day we hear the knock  And find the joke’s on me and you.

War’s a joke for me and you—  A jest we make to mask the fear,  But laughter echoes strangely true  When peace is fragile, trembling near.  So let us laugh, but let us know  The price of every careless show.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

responses.text: He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—  The world behind them flickers, wild and wide,  A thousand storms compressed in one disguise,  Unruly tides he struggles not to hide.  His gaze, a flicker through the trembling dusk,  Unsettles shadows sleeping on the floor.  His thoughts, sharp whispers, tangled in the musk  Of dreams and nightmares crashing at the door.  What secrets coil behind that haunted stare?  What labyrinth of sorrow, wrath, or fire?  His laughter cracks the silence, cold and bare,  A brittle echo of some lost desire.  Yet in that chaos, something calls to me—  A flicker of a boy who once was kind,  A plea for mercy no one else can see,  A trembling hope he scarcely dares to find.  So though his eyes are wild as broken glass,  I hold his gaze, and will not let him pass.  For in the madness, love might yet remain—  A fragile thread, unbroken by the pain.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

responses.text: Blessed be Thou for all the joy  That threads through dawn’s unfolding light,  For laughter, soft as down, employed  To make the sharpest burdens slight. prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text: People are happy in the gentle hush  Of mornings bright with dew and hope anew—  They gather sunlight in their arms, and brush  Away the shadows that the night once threw.  Laughter spills like rivers through the street,  A melody of footsteps on the stone,  Strangers exchanging smiles when they meet,  Finding warmth and kinship they’d never known.  People are happy in the simplest ways:  A child’s hand in theirs, the scent of bread,  A song remembered from forgotten days,  A garden blooming where old worries fled.  Their happiness is humble, soft, and clear,  A quiet promise whispered ear to ear.  Yet in each face, a thousand stories sleep—  Joys and sorrows folded deep within—  Still, in the open air, their spirits leap,  Hearts unburdened, lighter than they’ve been.  People are happy, though the world is wide;  In fleeting moments, side by hopeful side.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text: People are happy—so the world believes—  In city parks where laughter threads the trees,  On sunlit benches, sipping coffee, warm,  A thousand tiny joys in quiet form. Yet happiness is fleeting, quick to roam,  A guest that visits even aching homes.  It dances at the edges of our sight,  A flutter in the chest, a flare of light.  People are happy in the in-between—  A moment’s peace, a breath, a space unseen.  And sometimes, in the hush before the dawn,  Their happiness is something they have drawn.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text: People are happy—so the sparrows sing,  Their laughter tumbling through the open air,  A kite ascending on a hopeful string,  Fresh petals curling in a child’s hair. prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text: People are happy, or so the stories go—  In markets bustling under lantern light,  Where hands exchange the colors they bestow  And laughter drifts like ribbons out of sight. People are happy, yes—but not always—  Their joy is stitched with longing, love, and haze.  It’s found between the silences and sighs,  A fragile thing, but one that always tries.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text: People are happy—at least, that’s what we say,  As sunlight skips across the breakfast table,  And children trace their names in clouds of gray,  While stories flicker softly on the cable. They are happy in the way the city hums—  A thousand lives all woven, close and bright,  In every window, hope or heartache comes,  But still, they gather warmth from borrowed light.  You’ll find their joy in notes left on a fridge,  In wild applause, or whispered, secret grins,  In bridges built across a heavy ridge,  And every finish line where one begins.  People are happy, sometimes just for now—  In messes left behind from baking bread,  In learning joy is not a solemn vow,  But something growing quietly instead.  So, let the world keep asking if it’s true—  People are happy, and so are you.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,'

responses.text: The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,  A whisper in the garden where innocence once fell.  Green leaves shivered softly, secrets in their veins,  While sunlight danced on branches, shielding ancient stains.A silver tongue flickered, weaving riddles through the air,  Promising a wisdom, a freedom—something rare.  The fruit in her fingers, so heavy and bright,  Held the taste of beginnings and the end of delight.With a bite came the thunder, the world split in two,  Petals bruised and trembling, dew replaced by rue.  No serpent’s apology, no apple’s regret,  Just footprints in the clover, damp with dew and sweat.Yet still in the telling, the garden remains—  A symbol of longing, of knowledge, of chains.  We wander its shadows, both cursed and compelled,  For the snake and the apple is a tale we all tell.So let the story linger in the hush before dawn,  A warning, a question, a path to walk on.  In every temptation, in each secret well—  The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,'

responses.text: The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell—  A story etched in echoes, in shadows where we dwell. Yet, perhaps there’s more than sorrow in the tale we know—  A spark of understanding, a seed that we sow.  For knowledge is a double-edged, ever-turning blade;  It wounds as it enlightens, in sunlight and in shade.  So, we retell the story, as warning and as guide,  Of yearning, choice, and consequence that ever coincide.  The snake and the apple—both curse and gift as well—  A sorry tale to ponder, and a mystery to dwell.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,'

responses.text: The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,  Of moonlit leaves and secrets where early shadows fell. We walk among the echoes, gardens lost and overgrown,  Wishing for a paradise that we have never known. The serpent, not a villain, but a voice that dared us try;  The fruit, not just an ending, but the knowledge how to fly.  So mourn the faded garden, but cherish too the leap—  For every sorry story sows the dreams we choose to keep.  The snake and the apple—such a sorry tale to tell,  Yet woven in our making, and the story we know well.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,'

responses.text: The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,  Winding through the ages with a bittersweet spell. prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,'

responses.text: The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,  A tale of dawn’s unraveling, where hallowed shadows fell. prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text: My God, how many are my fears!  Like shadows weaving through my years,  They whisper doubts at midnight’s gate,  And paint my dreams with strokes of fate.  Each morning’s light, a trembling hush,  As hope and worry softly brush—  The trembling leaves outside my door  Echo the fears I can’t ignore.  They gather in the silent room,  A host of ghosts from ancient gloom;  Regret, and loss, and things undone,  Parade beneath the rising sun.  My God, you see these secret woes,  The anxious heart that no one knows,  Yet in the darkness, faint and small,  A gentle voice begins to call:  “Fear not the shadows as they pass,  Nor weep for moments lost, alas—  For every trembling, tearful prayer  Is met with love, and answered there.”  So let the fears come as they will,  Like autumn leaves, they fall, are still;  My God, you count them, one by one—  And soothe the heart when day is done.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text: My God, how many are my fears!  They gather like rain on windowpanes,  Tapping a code I cannot read,  A language born of storm and stain.  They crowd the room where silence lives,  Carve cold initials on my bones,  And tiptoe through my waking thoughts  In voices only I have known.  At dusk, they hide within the trees,  Or curl like smoke beneath the door,  Familiar as a childhood tune  Played on a cracked and haunted floor.  But still I rise and face the dawn,  Despite the trembling in my chest;  For every fear that stalks my steps,  I find a fragment of my rest.  My God, how many are my fears!  Yet count them gently, one by one—  They are the proof that I am here,  Alive, unfinished, and undone.  I gather courage from the dusk,  And cradle hope through sleepless nights;  For every fear that blots the moon  Is softened by the morning light.  So let the tally rise and fall—  I walk with fears, but walk through all.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text: My God, how many are my fears!  They bloom like wildflowers in the dusk—  Some bright and bold, some faint and hushed—  A secret garden I never chose,  Yet tend with trembling hands each night.  They curl beneath the kitchen light,  In quiet moments, when I pause—  The fear of loss, of time undone,  Of words I spoke or left unsaid,  Of doors unopened, bridges burned.  They wait in crowds behind my eyes,  A thousand faces, masked and strange,  Each whispering what might go wrong,  Each building castles made of sand  That tides of reason cannot reach.  Yet in this meadow of my mind,  A single blossom dares to rise—  A fragile hope, a stubborn peace,  That through the tangled, thorny fears  A softer morning might emerge.  So let me count them, name them all—  These fears that shape and shadow me—  For every fear that took me down  Has taught my heart to rise again,  To turn its face toward the sun.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text: My God, how many are my fears!  They flutter as moths in a lantern’s gleam,  Flickering wings against fragile glass—  Anxieties woven into the seams  Of every hope I dare let pass.  They gather by thousands in shadowed halls,  Whispering warnings in windless air,  A parliament of doubts that calls  With questions I can hardly bear.  My God, how many are my fears! Yet through the trembling, I find a thread—  A golden filament, hidden but real,  Winding through every dread-filled thread,  A promise that sorrow and pain can heal.  So let me cup these fears in hand,  Hold them up to the rising light;  For each is a lesson I must withstand,  A lantern burning through the night.  My God, how many are my fears!  Yet with every dawn, their chorus clears—  I walk, uncertain, but not alone,  For grace grows stronger than fear has grown.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text: My God, how many are my fears!  They gather in the early gray,  A parliament of worried crows  That circle overhead and say  The world is fraught, the night is long,  The path ahead is steep and strange.  They rattle windows, tap on walls,  Demanding time I cannot change.My God, how many are my fears!  They dress as thunder, wear the rain,  Slip through the cracks in hopeful thoughts,  And nest where memories remain.  They haunt the hush before the dawn,  Paint monsters on the ceiling’s white,  And count the hours until I sleep  To chase me through the fragile night.Yet in the clamor of their wings,  A hush persists—a whispered song  That dares me breathe, to move, to stand  And know these fears do not belong.  For just beyond the anxious dark,  A quiet courage waits for me,  Unfolding petals, soft and stark,  A promise of what life can be.My God, how many are my fears—  But hope, a single star, appears.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

responses.text: Blessed be Thou for all the joy  That spills like sunlight on the floor,  For laughter echoing in halls,  For gentle knocks at memory’s door.    Blessed the morning’s breath of gold  That lifts the hush of restless night,  And blessed the hands that reach and hold  When hope is trembling out of sight.    For every song that stirs the heart,  For kindness whispered, soft and shy,  For every chance to make a start  Beneath the wide, forgiving sky—    Blessed be Thou in petals bright,  In children’s dreams and lovers’ sighs,  In every tear that ends in light,  In every truth that time belies.    For grace that finds me unaware,  For peace that settles like a dove,  For every burden You repair—  Blessed be Thou, whose name is Love.  So let my spirit, clear and strong,  Rise up in thanks without alloy:  Blessed be Thou in every song,  Blessed be Thou for all the joy.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

responses.text: Blessed be Thou for all the joy—  For laughter woven through the days,  For sunlight glancing off the leaves,  For quiet corners filled with praise.  For morning dew on tangled grass,  For coffee warm against my hands,  For friendships deep as ancient roots,  For journeys no one understands.  Blessed be Thou for moments small:  The robin’s trill at break of dawn,  The hush that follows summer rain,  The promise wrapped in every yawn.  For memories that gently gleam  Like lanterns swinging in the dusk,  For stories shared and secrets kept,  For trust that grows from fragile husk. For art that colors weary minds,  For music rising, wild and free,  For hands to hold, for love that binds—  Blessed be Thou, who calls to me.  Let gratitude be what I sing  In every breath, through every hour;  Blessed be Thou for all the joy—  The world transformed by gentle power.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

responses.text: Blessed be Thou for all the joy—  For wildflowers that bloom unseen,  For every child’s delighted cry,  For spaces bright and in-between. Blessed be Thou for all the light  That finds me when the days are long,  For every star that splits the night,  For giving me the gift of song.  Blessed be Thou for all the joy—  A thousand thanks, a single voice.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

responses.text: Blessed be Thou for all the joy—  The fleeting spark in ordinary hours,  A shimmer in the mundane’s alloy,  The scent of earth after cooling showers. prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'
